content.raw:
Hi Ian,
I think teams will have issues with the heightmap descritrization - particularly the gradient entering and exiting the mud pit - which are about 45 degrees. As a result, entering and exiting the mud pit is more complicated than the rest of the entire task combined.

My understanding is that with the PNG height map, you only get 256 levels in total. But 90% of those levels are spent creating the mountains in the distance and only 10% are spent on variations of the terrain that the robot will walk on.

Can I suggest removing/lowering the mountains? With the 256 levels spaced between 0 and 2.5m you will get 1cm resolution making it possible to have gentle, gradual sloping out of the mud pit without discontinuities.

I'm happy to help with heightmap image processing if thats possible
content.html:

My understanding is that with the PNG height map, you only get 256 levels in total. But 90% of those levels are spent creating the mountains in the distance and only 10% are spent on variations of the terrain that the robot will walk on.

Can I suggest removing/lowering the mountains? With the 256 levels spaced between 0 and 2.5m you will get 1cm resolution making it possible to have gentle, gradual sloping out of the mud pit without discontinuities.

I'm happy to help with heightmap image processing if thats possible

content.raw: Hi Maurice, ok I'll improve the terrain resolution as you suggested, stay tunned

content.raw: Heightmap looks very good now I think and I haven't seen any big issues with heightmap penetration - however i haven't tried walking on it much yet so there might still be some potential penetration issues (when I place the polaris on the heightmap it sometimes receives a large impulse on one of the wheels causing it to jump up for half a meter or so, and I'm kind of scared of this happening to atlas as well), but it's much much better than the old heightmap.
content.html: Heightmap looks very good now I think and I haven't seen any big issues with heightmap penetration - however i haven't tried walking on it much yet so there might still be some potential penetration issues (when I place the polaris on the heightmap it sometimes receives a large impulse on one of the wheels causing it to jump up for half a meter or so, and I'm kind of scared of this happening to atlas as well), but it's much much better than the old heightmap.

content.raw:
Thomas, I see the same thing as you with polaris on the heightmap. On a hunch, I locally changed the collision geometry for the polaris wheels from cylinders to spheres I didn't observe the problem any further. I suspect that contact between cylinders and heightmaps is the issue, so it may not be problem for Atlas's rectangular feet. Keep an eye out.

It's easy to see if you add a cylinder to a heightmap; I'll report this as an issue on gazebo.

Edit: [gazebo issue 684](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/684)
content.html:
Thomas, I see the same thing as you with polaris on the heightmap. I suspect that contact between cylinders and heightmaps is the issue, so it may not be problem for Atlas's rectangular feet. Keep an eye out.

It's easy to see if you add a cylinder to a heightmap; I'll report this as an issue on gazebo.

Edit: gazebo issue 684

content.raw:
Hey guys,

I ran some walking tests on the new heightmaps and contact jitter still appears to be an issue when walking on the non-flat areas [1]. The jitter doesn't happen in any of the flat areas (debris field, bottom of the mud).

I'm using gazebo rev 7803 and drcsim rev 2441.

[1] Video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cEE7vjhhNbs (sorry for the choppiness).
